column1: Simon Roberts' dissolving portraits of a half-familiar London invite us to imagine a future transmuted by climate crisis. The city is de-peopled and eerie
column2: its landmarks re-imagined as monuments to a displaced past. The photographs speak of loss

column1: Simon Roberts is a British photographer renowned for his large-format
column2: tableaux-style images that explore the relationship between people and landscape
column3: focusing on themes of identity and belonging. Roberts has exhibited internationally
column4: with his photographs held in major collections such as the George Eastman Museum and the V&A.

column1: This is a collection of the world's most vibrant and inventive contemporary photography of flowers. From the garland wholesalers of Kolkata to wildflowers blooming between paving stones
column2: these images are a modern tribute to the enduring allure of flowers in both art and life.

Life is always winking at us
column2: calling our attention to the beauty hidden in plain sight. Why do we so often miss what's right in front of us
column3: lost in thought or tethered to endless to-do lists? This compilation of poems
column4: photographs and creative practices is for anyone looking to recover a sense of astonishment in ordinary things.

column1: An English summer is a precious thing: often short-lived but all the more tender for it. As the country contended with Brexit and Covid

column1: As many of us question the necessity of working from an office
column2: this photographic series – taken in the days before wifi and iPhones – is a poignant reminder of how things once were. Teetering stacks of paper
column4: gum-white computer monitors and the cold glow of the Xerox machine; what were once essential tools now stand as whimsical relics to a former life. The office holds bittersweet memories of kitchen small talk
column6: awkward Christmas parties and promotions won or lost. Capturing this corporate world with a tender yet satirical eye
column7: American photographer Steven Ahlgren’s nostalgic series will resonate with anyone who has ever loved
column8: hated or simply endured office life.

This book is a playful conversation between two important bodies of photographic work. Each spread of Déjà View pairs one of Martin Parr’s iconic snapshots with an image from The Anonymous Project’s collection of found amateur photographs taken between the 1950s and 80s. These unnervingly similar ‘twin’ pictures remind us of photography’s greatest power: to intimately preserve everyday moments of humour
Martin Parr is one of Britain’s most esteemed and well-loved photographers; he has published around 40 solo photobooks and has been a member of Magnum Photos for nearly 30 years.
The Anonymous Project is dedicated to collecting and preserving mid-century colour slides from around the world. Started in 2017 by filmmaker Lee Shulman
column2: the project brings to light Kodachrome memories that might otherwise be lost forever.

filled with humanity and compassion – and proof of the deep love that fathers have for their children.‘ Alain de Botton

column1: Brent has a rich history of multiculturalism. Roy Mehta’s exquisite black and white photographs capture the daily rituals of its various communities
column2: most notably the Afro-Caribbean and Irish
column3: engaged in seemingly simple activities at home
column4: in the street and at church. Shot from 1989–1993
column5: the images move from profound moments of faith to quiet family settings to the noisy streets outside
column6: reminding us of the continual opportunities for connection and reflection in everyday life.

column1: ‘Mehta doesn’t shy away from the sadness and difficulties of this foundational story
column2: but his multiracial faces – taken in Brent
column3: northwest London – remain coloured with British dreams
column4: and they exude a vitality which suggests that
column5: although things are never going to be easy

column1: Roy Mehta is a well-established London-based photographic artist with thirty years of professional experience working on personal and commercial projects. This is his third book.

made spontaneously on the streets of east London

In the wake of a terror attack and determined not to let the voices of separatism win out
column2: photographer Katie Waggett embarked on an intimate survey of London’s many religions. Her portraits of individuals in their most colourful religious outfits are accompanied by personal quotes
column3: as well interiors from the places of worship. Sunday Best is a feast of colour and a love letter to a city that so depends on diversity for its survival.

column1: Paul Trevor began to make pictures in his Brick Lane neighbourhood after abandoning his job as an accountant and deciding to become a photographer at the age of 25. His photographs have been exhibited internationally since the 1970s and are in public and private collections worldwide.

column3: these richly-detailed photographs capture the candyfloss colours and faded nostalgia of a seaside culture that is peculiarly (yet wonderfully) British.

column4: some don’t get on. These powerful portraits tap into one of the most fascinating of all human relationships.

column1: Sophie Harris-Taylor is a fine art and portrait photographer

column3: is well known for its vibrant creative community. Jenny Lewis spent four years in and out of studios across the borough photographing a tribe of artists who over time have defined the area. Painters
column7: ceramicists and fashion designers invite us into their studios and share their private thoughts about the creative process.

column1: Jenny Lewis moved to Hackney over twenty years ago via a spell at Preston University where she acquired a Fine Art degree and a husband. Her first book

column1: Badly Repaired Cars;Ronni Campana;FALSE;"72pp hardcover with tip-in image and foiled titling
SELECTED AS ONE OF MARTIN PARR'S BEST PHOTOBOOKS OF 2016
Badly Repaired Cars is a bright
column2: bold and humorous documentation of some of the best (or worst) examples of DIY car repairs. Close up photographs of cars held together by tape
column3: plastic and glue fill each frame and begin to take on the qualities of abstract art. A strip of duct tape across a broken headlight becomes powerfully graphic in form; green plastic hanging from a door divides the frame like a Rothko colour wash.

column1: This is Book 2 in a series that celebrates the best in colourful

column2: photographer Ronni Campana specialises in photographing the world’s minute imperfections. By concentrating on details in his surrounding environment and framing contrasting colour and shapes he uncovers an abstract beauty in seemingly mundane objects. With the use of subtle humour and a bright flash he draws our attention to the wonderful flaws found in everyday life. This is his first book.

column1: This is Book 1 in a series that celebrates the best in colourful
Emily Stein started taking photographs in the last term of her Fine Art degree. Never able to concentrate for long enough to finish a painting
column2: she picked up a camera and immediately fell in love with photography. Taking pictures enabled her two great loves: going on adventures and meeting new people. These days she photographs people of all ages
column3: often for commercial clients such as MTV
column5: and has a natural gift for capturing their energy and individuality.
